prior_works.title: Trichromacy, opponent colours and optimum colour coding
prior_works.role: Efficient coding theory of color opponency
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established that decorrelating cone signals yields opponent-color channels, directly motivating the paper’s core idea that cortical learning can infer the correct color dimensionality from optic nerve statistics.

prior_works.title: Understanding Retinal Color Coding from First Principles
prior_works.authors: J. J. Atick, Z. Li, A. N. Redlich
prior_works.role: Theoretical derivation of opponent coding from natural scene statistics
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provided a principled efficient-coding account of how natural image statistics and cone sensitivities lead to opponent channels, underpinning the framework’s assumption that dimensionality can emerge from input fluctuations.

prior_works.title: Statistics of cone responses to natural images: Implications for visual coding
prior_works.authors: D. L. Ruderman, T. W. Cronin, C.-C. Chiao
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Quantified the correlations and variances in L, M, S cone excitations for natural scenes, directly informing the simulation engine’s optic-nerve signal generation and the learning signals that drive emergent color dimensions.

prior_works.title: Chromatic mechanisms in lateral geniculate nucleus of macaque
prior_works.authors: A. M. Derrington, J. Krauskopf, P. Lennie
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Empirically characterized L–M and S–(L+M) mechanisms that serve as a biological target for the model’s emergent internal color space and a benchmark for validating inferred dimensionality.

prior_works.title: A simplified neuron model as a principal component analyzer
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced a Hebbian/normalization rule that discovers principal components, directly enabling the paper’s bio-plausible cortical learning to infer the number and axes of chromatic dimensions from optic nerve fluctuations.

prior_works.title: Independent Component Analysis: Algorithms and Applications
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Showed that ICA on natural images recovers opponent chromatic channels, supporting the paper’s claim that cortical circuits can learn an appropriate low-dimensional color basis from sensory input statistics.

prior_works.title: A computational observer model of spatial contrast sensitivity: Predicting performance of human observers
prior_works.authors: N. P. Cottaris, H. Jiang, D. H. Brainard, B. A. Wandell
prior_works.role: End-to-end eye and early vision simulation (ISETBio paradigm)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Demonstrated a scene-to-retina computational pipeline (optics, cone sampling, retinal encoding) that the paper extends to generate realistic optic nerve signals driving cortical learning of color dimensionality.

synthesis_narrative: The paper’s key contribution—an end-to-end framework in which cortical circuits infer the brain’s internal color dimensionality directly from optic nerve signals—rests on three intertwined intellectual strands. First, efficient coding theories of color (Buchsbaum & Gottschalk; Atick, Li & Redlich) established that decorrelating cone inputs under natural-image statistics yields opponent channels, implying that dimensional structure can, in principle, be recovered from sensory fluctuations without supervision. Complementing this, Ruderman, Cronin & Chiao quantified the actual statistics of L, M, and S cone responses to natural scenes, providing the empirical substrate necessary for a realistic simulation of the optic nerve signals that drive learning. Second, physiological characterizations of chromatic pathways (Derrington, Krauskopf & Lennie) identified L–M and S–(L+M) mechanisms, offering concrete targets against which emergent internal representations can be validated. Third, bio-plausible unsupervised learning rules (Oja) and independent component analyses (Hyvärinen & Oja) demonstrated how neural circuits can discover low-dimensional, opponent-like bases from input statistics, directly informing the cortical learning component that infers dimensionality. Finally, computational observer frameworks for early vision (Cottaris et al.) showed how to synthesize optics, cone mosaics, and retinal encoding from natural images, which this work leverages and extends to generate the optic nerve fluctuations needed for learning. Together, these works directly enable and shape the paper’s central innovation: joint simulation of eye and cortex to explain the emergence and identification of the brain’s color dimensionality.
